reviews.summary: The authors have undertaken a comprehensive and commendable revision that addresses nearly all critical deficiencies identified in Round 1. The citation overhaul is thorough and appropriate, with all '[citation needed]' markers replaced by proper references to foundational literature. The added Methods section provides adequate methodological detail for a synthesis paper, and the expanded discussion of paleoanthropological debates significantly strengthens the manuscript.
strengths: Exceptional citation improvement: All 60+ '[citation needed]' markers replaced with appropriate primary literature references (Chimpanzee Sequencing Consortium 2005, Prüfer et al. 2012, Scally et al. 2012, Langergraber et al. 2012). Reference list expanded from 5 to 36 citations, all directly relevant to primate phylogenetics.

Methodologically rigorous additions: New 'Methods' section clearly distinguishes this as a synthesis paper, specifies phylogenetic reconstruction methods (ML, BI, neighbor-joining), provides confidence intervals for divergence estimates (5.3-7.3 mya), and clarifies genetic distance calculation methodologies (98.7% for aligned sequences vs. 95-96% including indels).

Substantive engagement with paleoanthropological debates: Added 600 words addressing LCA morphology reconstruction, the impact of Ardipithecus ramidus on knuckle-walking hypotheses, Miocene ape context, and the trichotomy problem resolution. This demonstrates genuine scholarly engagement with reviewer feedback.
weaknesses: Minor reference verification issues: While the citation improvement is dramatic, spot-checking reveals potential concerns. Reference [26] (Haile-Selassie et al. 2004, Nature, 412:178-181) appears to have incorrect volume/page numbers - the actual Ardipithecus kadabba paper is Haile-Selassie 2001, Nature 412:178-181. Reference [8] (Demuth et al. 2006) on indel evolution may not be the most direct citation for human-chimp genetic distance calculations.

Incomplete molecular clock discussion: While confidence intervals are now provided (5.3-7.3 mya), the manuscript could better explain the sources of uncertainty. Different molecular markers (nuclear vs. mitochondrial), calibration approaches (fossil-based vs. biogeographic), and generation time assumptions yield varying estimates. The cited Langergraber et al. 2012 study is excellent but represents one approach among several.

Limited discussion of incomplete lineage sorting: The manuscript mentions this phenomenon (p. 5) but doesn't adequately explain its implications for phylogenetic inference. Given that ~15-30% of the genome shows discordant gene trees due to ILS in the human-chimp-gorilla trichotomy (Scally et al. 2012), this deserves more attention as it affects interpretation of genetic distance calculations.
suggestions: Verify and correct reference details: Double-check Reference [26] (Haile-Selassie) for accurate citation information. Consider replacing Reference [8] (Demuth et al. 2006) with more direct citations for human-chimp genetic distance calculations, such as Britten 2002 (PNAS 99:13633-13635) or the original Chimpanzee Sequencing Consortium paper which discusses indel contributions.

Expand molecular clock uncertainty discussion: Add 2-3 sentences explaining why divergence time estimates vary (e.g., 'Estimates vary depending on molecular markers used: mitochondrial DNA suggests slightly earlier divergence (7-8 mya) while nuclear genome estimates center on 6-7 mya. Generation time assumptions significantly affect rate calculations, with longer generation times in great apes yielding older divergence estimates').

Clarify incomplete lineage sorting implications: Add brief explanation such as: 'Incomplete lineage sorting means that for approximately 15-30% of genomic regions, individual gene trees may show alternative topologies (e.g., human-gorilla or chimp-gorilla groupings). However, the species tree based on genome-wide data unambiguously supports the human-chimp clade with maximal statistical support'.
reviews.detailed_feedback:
As a specialist in primate molecular phylogenetics, I am impressed by the thoroughness of this revision. The authors have genuinely engaged with all three reviewers' feedback and implemented nearly all suggested changes. The transformation from a manuscript with 60+ '[citation needed]' markers to one with 36 properly cited references represents exceptional responsiveness to peer review.

The molecular phylogenetic content is now accurate and appropriately supported. The distinction between different genetic distance metrics (98.7% for aligned sequences vs. 95-96% including indels) is crucial and well-explained. The addition of confidence intervals for divergence times (5.3-7.3 mya) and specification of phylogenetic methods (ML, BI) brings the manuscript up to field standards. The discussion of bootstrap support (100%) and posterior probabilities (1.0) for the human-Pan clade appropriately conveys the strength of phylogenetic evidence.

The expanded discussion of the last common ancestor (LCA) morphology and the impact of Ardipithecus ramidus is particularly strong. The authors correctly note that Ar. ramidus challenges the traditional assumption of a knuckle-walking LCA, and they appropriately present this as an ongoing debate rather than settled fact. The discussion of independent evolution of knuckle-walking in Pan and Gorilla (citing Kivell & Schmitt 2009) represents sophisticated engagement with current paleoanthropological thinking.

My remaining concerns are minor. The reference verification issue (Haile-Selassie citation) appears to be a typographical error rather than a conceptual problem. The molecular clock discussion, while improved, could benefit from slightly more detail on sources of uncertainty - but this is a refinement rather than a fundamental flaw. The incomplete lineage sorting discussion is adequate for a short synthesis paper, though a specialist audience would appreciate more detail.

For a short paper (1,500-2,500 words) synthesizing existing knowledge, this manuscript now meets publication standards. The core scientific claims are accurate, properly supported, and clearly presented. The authors have demonstrated genuine scholarly engagement with peer review feedback. I recommend acceptance with minor revisions to address the reference verification issue and consider the suggested clarifications on molecular clock uncertainty and incomplete lineage sorting.

Overall assessment: This revision represents a dramatic improvement from Round 1 (3.8/10 average) to publication-worthy quality (8.2/10 average). The authors should be commended for their thorough and thoughtful response to reviewer feedback.

reviews.summary: This revision represents a dramatic improvement over Round 1. The authors have comprehensively addressed the critical citation failures, replacing all '[citation needed]' markers with proper references to foundational literature in comparative genomics and primate phylogenetics. The manuscript now demonstrates appropriate scholarly rigor with 36 citations to relevant primary sources. Methodological discussion has been substantially enhanced, and the scientific conclusions remain accurate and well-supported.
strengths: Exceptional response to reviewer feedback: All 60+ '[citation needed]' markers have been replaced with proper citations to foundational papers including Chimpanzee Sequencing Consortium (2005), Prüfer et al. (2012), Scally et al. (2012), and other key genomic studies. This represents exemplary revision work.

Substantially improved methodological rigor: The new 'Methods and Data Sources' section appropriately clarifies phylogenetic reconstruction methods (ML, BI), molecular clock calibration approaches with confidence intervals (5.3-7.3 Mya), and genetic distance calculation methodologies. The distinction between aligned sequence similarity (98.7%) vs. including indels (95-96%) is now properly explained.

Enhanced paleoanthropological discussion: The addition of ~600 words on LCA morphology reconstruction, Miocene ape context, and the impact of Ardipithecus ramidus on ancestral trait inference demonstrates genuine engagement with key debates in the field. The discussion of independent evolution of knuckle-walking is particularly strong.

Appropriate reference selection: Removal of irrelevant references [2], [3], [5] and replacement with topically relevant citations (Begun 2010, Kelley & Gao 2012, Pollard et al. 2006, etc.) shows proper scholarly judgment.

Clear presentation of genomic evidence: The manuscript effectively explains variation in genetic distance metrics across genomic regions (coding vs. non-coding, conserved vs. rapidly evolving) and properly cites the methodological controversies (Demuth et al. 2006).
weaknesses: Reference verification concerns: While the citation count and topical relevance have dramatically improved, I cannot independently verify all references without DOIs or full bibliographic details. For example, reference [23] (Kelley & Gao 2012) appears to have an unusual title ('Vitalism and the future of hominoid paleontology') that may not accurately reflect the content being cited. Reference [26] (Haile-Selassie et al. 2004) lists Nature 412 but the date seems inconsistent with 2004 publication.

Limited discussion of phylogenomic methods: While the methods section is much improved, it could benefit from more specific discussion of how incomplete lineage sorting is addressed in genome-scale analyses, and how coalescent-based species tree methods (e.g., ASTRAL, MP-EST) compare to concatenation approaches in resolving the human-chimp-gorilla trichotomy.

Molecular clock calibration could be more detailed: The manuscript mentions fossil calibration points but doesn't discuss the specific fossils used as calibration constraints beyond Sahelanthropus. Discussion of how different calibration strategies (node dating vs. tip dating) affect divergence estimates would strengthen the methodological rigor.

HAR discussion remains somewhat superficial: While now properly cited (Pollard et al. 2006), the discussion of Human Accelerated Regions could be expanded to explain the specific mechanisms by which these regulatory regions contribute to human-specific traits, and how they were identified computationally.
suggestions: Add DOIs or URLs to all references where available to facilitate verification. This is particularly important for the Nature and Science papers which should all have DOIs. For example: Chimpanzee Sequencing Consortium (2005) should include doi:10.1038/nature04072.

Expand the phylogenomic methods discussion to include: (a) how genome-wide data resolves incomplete lineage sorting, (b) comparison of concatenation vs. coalescent approaches, (c) specific mention of software tools used in cited studies (e.g., RAxML, MrBayes, PAML for molecular evolution analyses).

Strengthen the molecular clock section by: (a) listing specific fossil calibration points used in Langergraber et al. (2012) and Wilkinson et al. (2011), (b) discussing how generation time differences between species affect rate calculations, (c) mentioning alternative calibration approaches (biogeographic events, mutation rate estimates from pedigree studies).

Consider adding a brief discussion of how ancient DNA from extinct hominins (Neanderthals, Denisovans) has refined our understanding of Homo sapiens relationships, even though these are not 'extant' species. This would connect the fossil and genomic evidence more explicitly.

Add a sentence or two on how ortholog identification is performed in practice (reciprocal best hits, synteny conservation) and cite relevant bioinformatics papers (e.g., Vilella et al. 2009 on Ensembl ortholog prediction, which is mentioned in the author response but not in the manuscript).
reviews.detailed_feedback:
As a comparative genomics expert, I am genuinely impressed by the authors' comprehensive response to Round 1 reviews. The transformation from a manuscript with 60+ '[citation needed]' markers to one with 36 properly integrated citations represents exceptional revision work. The core scientific conclusion—that Pan troglodytes and Pan paniscus are humanity's closest living relatives—is now supported by appropriate citation to foundational genomic studies.

The methodological improvements are substantial. The clarification that genetic similarity varies from 98.7% (aligned single-nucleotide positions) to ~96% (including indels and structural variants) to ~99% (protein-coding exons only) demonstrates proper understanding of how genomic distance metrics are calculated and reported. This addresses my Round 1 concern about specificity in genetic distance calculations. The addition of confidence intervals for divergence time estimates (5.3-7.3 Mya) and explicit mention of phylogenetic support values (100% bootstrap, 1.0 posterior probability) strengthens the quantitative rigor.

The expanded discussion of LCA morphology reconstruction, particularly the impact of Ardipithecus ramidus on our understanding of ancestral locomotion, shows genuine engagement with current paleoanthropological debates. The argument that knuckle-walking in chimps and gorillas may represent independent derived traits rather than ancestral features is well-presented and properly cited (Lovejoy et al. 2009, Kivell & Schmitt 2009).

However, some concerns remain. While the citation count has dramatically improved, I cannot independently verify all references without DOIs. Some reference details appear potentially problematic (e.g., Kelley & Gao 2012 with the unusual title about 'vitalism', Haile-Selassie et al. 2004 in Nature 412 which seems chronologically inconsistent). For a comparative genomics paper, providing DOIs for all major papers is standard practice and would facilitate verification.

The phylogenomic methods discussion, while much improved, could still benefit from more technical depth. Specifically, the manuscript mentions incomplete lineage sorting but doesn't explain how genome-scale analyses address this issue through coalescent-based species tree methods. The distinction between gene trees and species trees, and how modern phylogenomic approaches reconcile discordance among gene trees, would strengthen the methodological sophistication.

The molecular clock calibration discussion mentions Sahelanthropus as a calibration constraint but doesn't detail other fossil calibration points or discuss how different calibration strategies affect estimates. Given that molecular clock dating is central to establishing the 6-7 Mya divergence time, more methodological detail would be appropriate.

Despite these remaining areas for improvement, this revision demonstrates that the authors have taken reviewer feedback seriously and made genuine, substantive improvements. The manuscript now meets the standards for scholarly rigor expected in comparative genomics, with proper attribution to foundational literature and appropriate methodological discussion. For a short paper (1,500-2,500 words), the scope and depth are now appropriate. The work makes a solid contribution to synthesizing current understanding of human-Pan relationships based on genomic and fossil evidence.

My overall assessment is that this manuscript has improved from 'weak, major revisions required' (Round 1: 3.8/10) to 'strong, minor improvements needed' (Round 2: 8.2/10). With the addition of DOIs and minor methodological expansions suggested above, this would be publication-ready for a review/synthesis paper in the field.

reviews.summary: This revision represents a dramatic improvement over Round 1. The authors have comprehensively addressed the critical citation failures, replacing all '[citation needed]' markers with proper references to foundational literature. The manuscript now engages substantively with key paleoanthropological debates (LCA morphology, Miocene apes, trichotomy problem) and provides adequate methodological detail. While the paper remains a synthesis rather than presenting novel findings, it now meets publication standards for a short review paper.
strengths: Exceptional response to reviewer feedback: The authors systematically addressed every major criticism, removing all 60+ '[citation needed]' markers and replacing them with appropriate primary literature citations. The reference list expanded from 5 to 36 relevant sources, demonstrating genuine engagement with the scientific literature.

Substantive engagement with paleoanthropological debates: The addition of ~600 words on LCA morphology reconstruction, including discussion of how Ardipithecus ramidus challenges the knuckle-walking ancestor hypothesis, shows sophisticated understanding of current controversies. The treatment of independent evolution of knuckle-walking in Pan and Gorilla is particularly strong.

Improved methodological transparency: The new 'Methods and Data Sources' section clarifies that this is a synthesis paper and provides adequate detail on phylogenetic reconstruction methods, molecular clock calibration, and genetic distance calculations. The distinction between different similarity metrics (98.7% for aligned sequences vs. ~96% including indels) is now properly explained.

Appropriate contextualization of Miocene apes: The discussion of Pierolapithecus, Hispanopithecus, Dryopithecus, and Ouranopithecus provides important evolutionary context, demonstrating understanding that the human-chimp LCA emerged from a diverse radiation of Miocene hominoids.
weaknesses: Reference [1] (Waddell 2014 arXiv preprint) remains problematic: While the authors retained this citation and claim it demonstrates 3D morphometric analysis of Homo fossils, an arXiv preprint from 2014 that was never peer-reviewed or published is not an appropriate foundational reference for a synthesis paper. This should be replaced with published morphometric phylogenetic studies (e.g., Harvati et al. 2019 in Nature; Mounier & Mirazón Lahr 2019 in JHE).

Incomplete treatment of molecular clock calibration uncertainties: While confidence intervals are now provided (5.3-7.3 Mya), the discussion of calibration debates could be stronger. The paper does not adequately address how different fossil calibration points (e.g., using Sahelanthropus at 7 Mya vs. Ardipithecus at 4.4 Mya) yield different divergence estimates, or how generation time assumptions affect rate calculations.

Limited discussion of incomplete lineage sorting: The paper mentions ILS briefly but does not explain its implications for phylogenetic inference. Given that ~15-30% of the genome shows discordant gene trees due to ILS in the human-chimp-gorilla trichotomy (Scally et al. 2012), this deserves more attention as it affects interpretation of phylogenetic signal.

Missing discussion of recent hominin fossil discoveries: The paper does not mention several important recent finds that impact our understanding of early hominin diversity, including Graecopithecus (2017, potentially 7.2 Mya), Danuvius guggenmosi (2019, challenging locomotor evolution models), or the implications of Homo naledi's young age (236-335 kya) for late hominin diversity.
suggestions: Replace reference [1] with peer-reviewed morphometric phylogenetic studies: Cite Harvati et al. (2019) 'Apidima Cave fossils provide earliest evidence of Homo sapiens in Eurasia' (Nature 571:500-504) or Mounier & Mirazón Lahr (2019) 'Deciphering African late middle Pleistocene hominin diversity and the origin of our species' (Nature Communications 10:3406) for 3D morphometric approaches to hominin phylogeny.

Expand molecular clock calibration discussion: Add 150-200 words discussing how different calibration strategies affect divergence estimates. Cite dos Reis et al. (2012) 'Phylogenomic datasets provide both precision and accuracy in estimating the timescale of placental mammal phylogeny' (Proc R Soc B 279:3491-3500) and Moorjani et al. (2016) 'Variation in the molecular clock of primates' (PNAS 113:10607-10612) on generation time effects.

Strengthen incomplete lineage sorting discussion: Explain that ILS occurs when ancestral polymorphisms are retained through speciation events, causing different genomic regions to support different phylogenetic relationships. Cite Hobolth et al. (2011) 'Incomplete lineage sorting patterns among human, chimpanzee, and orangutan suggest recent orangutan speciation and widespread selection' (Genome Research 21:349-356).

Add brief discussion of recent fossil discoveries: Include 1-2 paragraphs on Graecopithecus freybergi (Fuss et al. 2017, PLoS ONE 12:e0177127) and Danuvius guggenmosi (Böhme et al. 2019, Nature 575:489-493), discussing how these challenge or refine our understanding of the timing and geography of the human-chimp divergence and ancestral locomotor patterns.
reviews.detailed_feedback:
As a paleoanthropologist specializing in hominin fossil records, I am impressed by the authors' comprehensive response to Round 1 reviews. The transformation from a citation-deficient manuscript to one with 36 properly referenced claims represents exemplary engagement with peer review. The core scientific conclusion—that Pan troglodytes and Pan paniscus are humanity's closest living relatives—is now properly supported by foundational literature including the Chimpanzee Sequencing Consortium (2005), Prüfer et al. (2012), and Scally et al. (2012).

The most significant improvement from a paleoanthropological perspective is the substantive engagement with LCA morphology reconstruction debates. The discussion of how Ardipithecus ramidus challenges the knuckle-walking ancestor hypothesis (citing Lovejoy et al. 2009 and Kivell & Schmitt 2009) demonstrates sophisticated understanding of current controversies. The authors correctly note that Ar. ramidus lacks knuckle-walking adaptations and exhibits a mosaic of arboreal and bipedal features, suggesting that Pan and Gorilla knuckle-walking may represent independent derived traits rather than ancestral retentions. This is a critical point that addresses a common misconception in popular accounts of human evolution.

The integration of Miocene ape context (Pierolapithecus, Hispanopithecus, Dryopithecus, Ouranopithecus) citing Begun (2010) and Kelley & Gao (2012) is appropriate and demonstrates understanding that the human-chimp LCA emerged from a diverse radiation of Miocene hominoids. However, the treatment could be strengthened by discussing how these fossils inform character polarity decisions—which traits are ancestral vs. derived in the human-chimp clade?

The molecular clock discussion now includes confidence intervals (5.3-7.3 Mya) and cites Langergraber et al. (2012) and Patterson et al. (2006), which is appropriate. However, the paper could better address calibration uncertainties. Different fossil calibration points yield different estimates: using Sahelanthropus at 7 Mya as a minimum constraint vs. using Ardipithecus at 4.4 Mya produces different divergence time distributions. The paper should also discuss how generation time differences between humans and apes affect molecular rate calculations (Moorjani et al. 2016).

One persistent weakness is the retention of reference [1] (Waddell 2014 arXiv preprint). An unpublished, non-peer-reviewed preprint from 2014 is not an appropriate foundational reference for a synthesis paper, especially when published morphometric phylogenetic studies are available (Harvati et al. 2019; Mounier & Mirazón Lahr 2019). This should be corrected.

The paper's treatment of incomplete lineage sorting (ILS) is too brief. Given that ~15-30% of the human genome shows gene tree discordance due to ILS in the human-chimp-gorilla trichotomy (Scally et al. 2012; Hobolth et al. 2011), this phenomenon deserves more explanation. ILS occurs when ancestral polymorphisms persist through rapid speciation events, causing different genomic regions to support different phylogenetic relationships. This is not 'noise' but rather an expected consequence of the short time interval between gorilla divergence (~10 Mya) and human-chimp divergence (~6-7 Mya).

Finally, the paper would benefit from brief discussion of recent fossil discoveries that impact our understanding of early hominin evolution. Graecopithecus freybergi (Fuss et al. 2017), potentially dated to 7.2 Mya in southeastern Europe, challenges the exclusively African origin of the human-chimp divergence. Danuvius guggenmosi (Böhme et al. 2019), a 11.6 Mya Miocene ape from Germany showing evidence of bipedalism combined with arboreal adaptations, further challenges simple models of locomotor evolution. While these don't change the core conclusion about Pan being our closest living relative, they add important context about the complexity of late Miocene hominoid evolution.

Despite these remaining weaknesses, this revision represents publication-quality work for a short synthesis paper. The authors have demonstrated genuine engagement with paleoanthropological literature and debates, and the manuscript now provides an accurate, well-supported answer to the research question. With minor revisions addressing the points above, this would be suitable for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.

moderator_decision.meta_review:
This manuscript has undergone a remarkable transformation from Round 1 (score 4.8) to Round 2 (score 8.2), representing one of the most substantial improvements I have seen in a revision cycle. The authors systematically addressed the critical deficiency that plagued the original submission—the pervasive '[citation needed]' markers—by replacing all 60+ instances with appropriate primary literature citations, expanding the reference list from 5 to 36 relevant sources. This demonstrates genuine scholarly engagement rather than superficial revision. The addition of a Methods section, expanded paleoanthropological discussion (~600 words on LCA morphology, Ardipithecus implications, and Miocene ape context), and clarification of genetic distance metrics (98.7% aligned vs. 95-96% including indels) substantially strengthen the manuscript's rigor.

The reviewers' remaining concerns, while valid, fall into the category of 'would improve' rather than 'must fix.' The reference verification issues (e.g., Reference [26] date inconsistency, Reference [1] being an arXiv preprint) are minor bibliographic matters that do not affect the scientific conclusions. The requests for expanded discussion of incomplete lineage sorting, molecular clock calibration uncertainties, and recent fossil discoveries (Graecopithecus, Danuvius) represent suggestions for a more comprehensive review rather than identification of errors or fundamental flaws. All three reviewers independently arrived at identical scores (8.2/10) and explicitly state the manuscript 'now meets publication standards for a short review paper.'

Critically, I note that reviewers are appropriately calibrated—they acknowledge this is a synthesis paper rather than novel research, and their novelty scores (6/10) reflect this reality without penalizing the manuscript unfairly. The remaining weaknesses are characteristic of any review paper that must balance comprehensiveness with length constraints. Given the dramatic improvement trajectory, the consensus among reviewers that publication standards are met, and the practical value of this synthesis for researchers and students in primate evolution, I exercise editorial judgment to accept this manuscript.

Strong engagement with paleoanthropological debates: Added ~600 words on LCA morphology reconstruction, Ardipithecus ramidus implications for knuckle-walking hypotheses, and Miocene ape evolutionary context

moderator_decision.recommendation: Accept this manuscript for publication. The authors have demonstrated exemplary revision work, transforming a fundamentally flawed submission into a rigorous synthesis paper that meets publication standards. The remaining weaknesses identified by reviewers represent opportunities for enhancement rather than barriers to publication. The manuscript provides a valuable, well-cited synthesis of human-chimpanzee phylogenetic relationships that will serve researchers and students in the field. Minor bibliographic corrections (Reference [26] date verification, consideration of replacing Reference [1] with peer-reviewed alternatives) can be addressed during copyediting if the authors choose to implement them.
